content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game, but very glitchy.Before I rain praise on this game (which I will, trust me), Let me get the negatives out of the way. CONS:-Beta, so it's very glitchy at times.-Character roles are not clearly defined (What's a Grenadier do, exactly? What's the difference between Line Infantry and Assault Infantry?)-Sound needs work at times.-Voluntary (?) game balance feature that can be easily ignored.-No land mines (remember, those were introduced in The Great War).And now, the praise:-FANTASTIC use of the Unity Engine-Historically very, very accurate.-An emphasis on realism, not gameplay that makes this that much better. -Heavy emphasis on squad-based tactics and infantry combat. -No player controllable tanks, aircraft or cavalry, keeping the game very balanced in firepower.-A true war sim that showed the horrors of trench warfare, chemical bombardment and constant shelling, along with fighting on grounds that obviously have been fought over for weeks to months, with little to no cover, using bolt-action weaponry.For all the Call Of Duty's, Battlefields and Counter-Strikes in the world, this is a fresh alternative. As a Yank, I would love to see an AEF-themed General Pershing Expansion in 2017 (100 years after the US got involved), along with an expansion into the Eastern front, pitting the White Russians against the Kaiser's troops until the Oktober Revolution ended the war on that side. I furiously recommend this game to ANYONE who likes realistic history-based war games. To the programmers & my fellow players; Great job, guys. See you on the front.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								There aren't a lot of WW1 shooters out there so I was surprised to see this, and even more surprised to see that the servers were fairly well populated. Oh, it's also pretty fun. That being said, its not for everyone, as afterall it is a WW1 shooter. The guns are all single shot rifles or heavy machine guns, and as a result you'll find yourself getting killed pretty often. Its also not the easiest game to get into and does require teamwork inorder to win, one guy with a bolt action rifle isnt going to clear a whole trench by himself. While the game is pretty fun, the battlefield is ruled by snipers which means that you will never see any machine gun nests since they all get sniped out pretty quickly. I think they should add some night levels to make the machine guns more playable and to reduce the amount of snipers, or add rainy levels or something. Overall it's pretty fun, however I think some balancing is needed and sometimes it crashes, although since it's still in beta I'll let that slide. Definitely get this if you're into WW1 history, and even if you're not you might want to consider it.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Super fun game. I've been waiting for a long time to play a World War One shooter, probably since Medal of Honor Rising Sun. This game is what I've been waiting for. There's a good squad element, and more strategic than other shooters out there. Verdun is very similar to Red Orchestra 2, with different roles and classes that specialize in certain combat situations. The community is for the most part helpful, there is more material on the way, and overall it is a fun game to play, especially with friends. The game is still in Beta, so not everything is perfect, there are sometimes frame rate drops, glitches(especially with cover system), and hit detection. I think I've only experienced glitches that crashed the game once in the past 70 hours. If you buy this game get used to being shot out of nowhere or shelled inside a trench, there is a bit of a learning curve. Overall it is worth the money. Follow your NCO, keep your head down, and charge for the Kaiser!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have wanted a good World War 1 first person shooter for a long time, and for a long time I heard people say "Oh it would be so boring. You would just charge and get shot down every time."Well now a World War 1 first person shooter is out and just in time for the 100th anniversary. They were partially right. I do charge and get shot down MOST of the time, but just as it says in "All Quiet on the Western Front" the new troops just charge across the open and die. The veterans know how to move along the ground from cover to cover, and getting into the enemy trench and clearing it out with bayonets, knives, clubs, and shovels is so satisfying. Some people say its hard, but if you work with a squad and move as a team its quite easy. The graphics have improved immensely since I first got this game but alas I am currently living over seas for a year and my good gaming computer is back at home so I can't witness this game at full graphics for another 5 or 6 months. The attack and defend with multiple layers of trenches makes for a fun game. You advance. If you are stopped then you fall back and prepare to defend your original trench. If you take their trench then you dig in and prepare to repulse a counter attack. The front is somewhat narrow to give you that World War 1 trench warfare feeling but its not so narrow that its completely impossible to move without dying. Sometimes you can sneak around if the enemy neglects a portion of their line, or you can gas or artillery barrage their lines to force an opening.All in all, if you are looking for a fun, squad based World War 1 first person shooter with a surprising variety of weapons and classes for a war 100 years ago then get this game, and I will see you out in no man's land.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Verdun is a shining example to other developers, showcasing what a successful 'Early Access' title looks like.Countless numbers of games have entered into 'Early Access,' only to see their developers lose interest once they've already made the bulk of their profits and have no real financial incentive to continue. That is absolutely not the case here--the development team on Verdun clearly has a personal commitment to seeing an online WWI FPS actualized. The most notable part of my experience playing was seeing how often updates and improvements were pushed out, as well as the sheer quality AND quantity; tons of new content, updated textures and animations, improved and balanced gameplay tweaks, performance patches, and even a large overhaul of the game's engine. Not at one single point during the development did it appear as though the developers were living off of their unfinished game, or abusing their fan base's loyalty to work extremely short hours. I'm thrilled to see the official release of this game, as well as it serving as an example of how 'Early Access' was able to positively influence a game throughout development.The game itself is quite fun; the mechanics are fleshed out and very unique. The game modes are nicely objective-oriented without feeling forced or arbitrary. Everything ranging from the game's graphics to its audio feel cohesive, giving an immersive feel of the era. If you've ever wished you could check out a WWI shooter, or simply want to support an indie developer that deserves it, this is your game.Other 'Early Access' developers, TAKE NOTES!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								With the hour that I've played Verdun, I can attest that it is a game whose developers have actually put quite a lot of effort behind their project and actually have a scope and plan. I can see Verdun becoming an actual game with a fairly large community, despite a bit of a niche of WWI games.First off, my complaints are that the art assets quite aren't there yet, but since this is Early Access it's forgivable, and I'll mostly just base these complaints on the current build as of writing (v173). The game isn't pretty in it's current state, it's not exactly "ugly" but some things like the lighting engine need work, and the models and textures a bit more refinment. My biggest problem in this department are the audio assets. Everything seems to lack volume and weight to the sound. Gunfire coming from a squadmate next to me sounds piddly and weak. Explosions are slightly better but still a tad under par.Another is that it feels a bit too... gamey, I suppose, rather than a much more immersive, realistic experience. Bullets don't currently have a drop yet, and currently uses a CoF (cone of fire) model as far as I can see, and a bit of a deadzone a la Red Orchestra as well as some ballistics physics would help immensely. As it stands, trying to fire a Webley at a target less than 50m away even while using ironsights is difficult to pull off. Movement is very floaty, and everything currently lacks weight.Another thing is that the game currently lacks VOIP, which makes it difficult to really communicate with your team although there is a text-chat system in place. What I'd like to see is maybe a "radio" chat within your squad (which needs to increase, btw, at most up to 6 or 8 players otherwise it may be difficult for large groups of friends to play together)My final complaint would that the game feels too small. 32 player combat, each with 4 squads of 4 fighting on 5 different maps ranging from smaller maps like Vosages to larger battles of Picardie. While a 32 player battle definitely feels right on Vosages, it feels sparse on much more larger maps. While no doubt more maps will be coming out soon of various sizes, those smaller maps would be better for Deathmatch rather than TDM which should host a larger player size (at least 64 but 96 would be fantastic, if even a bit of a stretch).So, why should you buy the game? Well so far the developers have done a pretty sweet job, despite my gripes above, but that's all they are for now. Most of that is simply based on what's been accomplished so far, and even in its early stage, it's still quite a playable game! The mechanics that are there aren't broken (but could use tweaking here and there), and there's enough players on at a time that it's not difficult to find yourself amongst a charge of screaming soldiers all before you're cutdown by MG and riflefire, and getting trapped in barbed-wire, because you didn't think it'd serve a purpose other than a prop, now did you?Would I recommend this game? Yes I would, but I'd advise watching some gameplay footage first, to see if the game would be right for you. And remember, although I wrote quite a bit on the flaws of this game, it's much easier to do so when the game is still in Alpha, not to mention that some of my own personal gripes might not be that big of a deal to yourself.

												After playing the game through Early Access and the Full Release, I must say that this game is possibly one of the best Squad-based tactical FPS out there if not the best. I think this is a great game that deserves more recognition.

content:

Early Access Review
								I started playing this about a year ago in June or so and was very impressed with how it played and how intense it was even through the bugs and funny animation. One of my favorite updates was the improved Rag-doll effect and since I usually play as Landsers NCO it is fun to watch the little French men fly up in the air after an Artillery Strike. The game kept improving a lot with the sound effects, animation and general design and feel getting better. I liked how nice and small the community was when I started and I felt a bond with other players who I've met. Now with a much larger and growing community, the game is truly starting to feel like a WWI game with massive numbers coming towards you.This game relies heavily on cooperation and pulling off strategic attacks. It really becomes better as time grows on and I like how the Squad Progression works out as it makes you want to play with friends more often and to be your best.My tip in playing NCO is to get near the enemy trench (if you're offence) and try your best to survive, find a nice hiding place inside the trench if possible, this will allow your teammates to spawn near you and make it easier to clear the trench.I'm probably the only or the few in game named "Erwin Rommel" if you want to find me to ask for tips or to just play together. I'm usually the NCO in any German Squad.*Edit: I should also add, I am not sure if it's the game's animation or just my internet that usually shows the enemy aiming at completely different area when he's actually aiming at you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Verdun - the best game about First World War since... ehm... hmm. This game proved that "boring" and "monotonous" trench warfare can be bloody fun. War is hell. You hear your commander whistle, you jump off the trench, you see your buddies run straight into chlorine cloud. Your squadmate tries to put on gas mask and misses the barbed wire, gets entangled in it. Your other friend turns to him, looks, thinks about helping him, but gets nailed with an enemy bullet. French, British, American, German, Canadian, Belgian... No man's land is just a giant mincer, chopping off your lives short. You see how people in front of you get mowed, running straight into machine gun crossfire. You have a split second to decide: do I crouch and turn back? Maybe I can get through? You are wrong. You will never get through. And even if by some miracle you make it to the enemy trench, you'll get ambushed by a rifleman, hiding behind a barrel. As the time goes, you'll see young soldiers become veterans with waxed moustaches, ready to die for their Fatherland. But is it really worth fighting?If you start thinking about it all, you might miss the command to retreat. The next thing you see is your lifeless body flying away, while the mortars hammer your position. Unless you affix your bayonet and charge your enemy, how dare you claim to know anything about true dirt and pain of virtual warfare? Get immersed into this painful world of war, and remember lads: It's a long long way to Tipperary

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												The Good: This isn't your normal first person shooter where you can run around on your own and rack up the points. Sure, you can do that in Verdun, but it won't get you anywhere very far. The gameplay is based around solid team work and good communication, something you don't normally expect to see worked into fps games often. It makes for an enjoyable and satisfying gameplay in a time setting that is not explored through games very well, but the sounds, guns, and different maps really put you feel like you're in the Great War, hunkering down trying to avoid bullets and artillery, and then sprinting to the enemy trench to take out the enemy. The Bad: There isn't really anything terrible that I have encountered yet in Verdun. I suppose one improvement I can suggest for the developers, however, is to somehow implement a tank or two on the battlefield, a major part of the war. You are able to use a lot of new "modern" weaponry in the game like grenades, machine guns, submachine guns, gas, and even planes, but no tanks. The team balancing sytem is a nice and welcome touch, but sometimes the game is too lopsided and things can turn south every game. Not sure exactly how to better that. In summary, it's a fun and creative WW1 fps. If you're looking for a different type of shooting game, I'd recommend this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												100 year anniversary of the battle of Verdun might as well do a review. Game is pretty awesome, highly recommend it. Not for run and gun shooter fans, this game takes patience, intelligence and team work. Each match plays like King of the Hill with a series of trenches, where one side defends and the other side attacks. If attackers take the defenders trench within the time limit (I think 5 minutes) then the timer is reset, and defending team has to retake their trench, if they fail to do so then they retreat to the next trench behind them. Eventually one side is either pushed too far back to their last trench, or the overall game timer runs out and the side who captured to most trenches win. The Squad system is pretty interesting, but with some issues. There are multiple squad types each having different rolls, and thus having different soldier types available, but most people play using the German Landers, French Poilues, or British Tommes squad types because they have the most streight forward soldier types in their squad; An officer who uses a pistol by default but can level up to have a rifle and can call in artillery, a Rifleman who can upgrade to be a sniper, A machine gunner who can use a machine gun (go figure), or a Grenadier who carries a lot of grenades.Apparently the squads themselves level up but from my experience once you create a squad there’s no way to find it when you stop playing and come back later. Usually I find myself joining free spots on existing squads anyway, so take this bit with a grain of salt. Overall a pretty cool Objective FPS that you can play with friends or by your self. Pros:-Great First Person Shooter, very tactical heavy requiring teamwork, brains and patience. -Straight forward role system that unlocks as you level up. -Various maps that have different challenges as you try to fight through them. -Non Toxic player community that is actually pleasent to banter with in the chat. Cons:-Player population very, sometimes its hard to get into a server, other times its deserted. -Wonky Animations, but they're still working on it. -Some LOD issues with terrain where you can sometimes see players through objects like sandbags or obstacles that are far away.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I lay in the trenches of the german first line listening to the mortars drop and the machine gun bullets wizzing by over my head. I take brief pod shots at the enemy line but have a hard time seeing anything through the grime and smoke. Then I hear an all too familair sound.....Für das Vaterland! Attacke! Attacke! Our NCO had just ordered us to charge the enemy lines and seeing that spreading cloud of chlorine gas on the horizon sure dident help puersuade the descision. I briefly considered shooting myself in the foot or hiding behind our line somewhere but what real soldier would do that? "Screw it" I thought, and with that I bounded up out of the trenches and proceeded to run for my life hearing noise of war and whistle of bullets all around me. Knowing if I hesitated now, even for a second, I would most likely end up facedown in the mud. Reminding myself of the noise variances akin to bullets, A hiss means its close but a snag means its a near miss. If you hear the latter then you better hit the ground like a fat man chasing a doughnut. Needless to say the next several minutes are a blurr of mud, screams, and smoke. Seeing several of my comrades fall in front of me and not get up again, knowing I might soon be joining them I close the bolt on my Grewher 98 as I get close enough to the enemy line to see heads moving about. Several of my fellows in a foxhole beside me raise up to run into the enemy trench which lay devestated from artillery fire, I notice movement in front of me. Several brits had rose up to take shots at my allies. I expose myself out of my fox hole and pick them off using 3 of my 5 shots earning myself 4 kills, as one of my bullets had went through my enemies neck and into his NCO behind him,  I see my friends scramble into the trench all safe from the horrors of No Mans Land. Then I see more movement on my right and turn to see the barrel of a MG sticking out amonst the sandbags. I close my eyes muttering a curse under my breath and accept my fate as I hear the sound of the machine gun open fire.I reopen my eyes and find myself back in the trench I had just fought my way out of just to do it all over again. Except now the enemy was charging us.9/10 would die for my friends againP.S. Listen to a Sabaton playlist while playing this, its OP as ♥♥♥♥ >:D

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Absolutely love this game.  I have played many FPS games, but this one is definitely unique.  As far as I know this is the only fully fledged WW1 first person shooter.  I have played the WW1 mod for BF1942 which was great, but nothing like this.    Verdun does remind me of Red Orchestra, but I actually enjoy this game more.  I have recently become more interested in everything WWI thanks to a podcast I listen to called Hardcore History by Dan Carlan.  So a couple months back I looked to see if there was a good WWI game that would represent the war well.  This game certainly does.  The trench warfare mode is fantastic and really replicates the fierce battles that those men had to endure.  The mechanics of the game are great.  There is a slight bullet drop, but nothing too noticeable. It is really more realistic than the bullet drop you would experience in Battlefield Bad Company 2.  The maps are fantastic and replicate the uniqueness of the war.  I hope that someday the battles will be increased to 48 or 64 players.  Problem is the server populations are pretty small right now.  Hopefully with the official release of the game more people will play.  This game is pretty difficult.  You will not be able to run and gun like you can in Call of Duty.  If you play Red Orchestra or Battlefield you may be able to not mind the long wait period to respawn.  Successfully capturing a trench will require patience and teamwork.  Gas and artillery strikes will be essential to pull this off in most battles, but this adds to the fun for me.  Highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												I'm a huge FPS lover, expecially those concerning WWII. This is definitely the best WWI FPS ever made, and one of the most realistic and difficoult FPS available right now. Pros:- It's a good WWI FPS, isn't that enough?-Realism is high. There are many details that amazed me, such as weapons (every army has its own ones used during the war), battlefields and tactics (throw arty/gas and then charge the enemy trench, defend your one with mgs)-Conquering an enemy trench after loosing many men is such an huge satisfaction! So it is defending it from the enemy charge that will try to take it back.-The squad system works very well.-The game succesfully manages to transport you in the WWI atmosphere with many details, such as menus, musics and images.Cons:-Not all maps are balanced. There are a few where the two opposing trenches are really unconquerable by both armies, vanishing in part the excellent balance made between the armies.-The game is really hard. sometimes frustrating. If you're an Insurgency/Red Orchestra player, you will find at home. If you come from more arcade FPS, you probably won't like this game.-There are a few bugs concerning bullet hits and directions. Sometimes, you will aim directly at an enemy, shoot at him and the bullet won't simply hit him.  -The maximum number of players in a map is 32, not very much if compared with other similar games like Red Orchestra 2 or Battlefield 4.Overall, I really appreciated this game, and I bet that every historical FPS lover will do the same. In the future, I hope that developers will fix the few bugs I found and add more maps, factions and theatres of war. Fighting at Gallipoli, Tannenberg and on the Isonzo river would be really amazing! 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												So I bought Verdun today for the Steam Summer sale and let me tell you, it is one of the best gaming experiences I have had. The game is unlike any other fps in the way it portrays warfare, and I felt like I was a small part of a bigger machine, instead of the main character. I booted up the game and joined a squad on the allied powers, looked breifly through the controls and got right into it.Verdun is a very easy game to get into, and it's immersiveness is unreal. I have a small story to tell about it too:So I joined a squad in the trench warfare gamemode (the main one), and the central powers were losing. I was in a german squad as a Bote (Bolt action, bayoneted rifle)It was the enemy's turn to attack, and they were pushing our right flank hard. My squad was holding the left flankSeveral people wanted to retreat and regroup, as much of our team was disorganized or deadI typed in chat "WE'RE HOLDING THE DAMN LINE"My team agreedPeople were typing "FUR DEUTSCHLAND"I sprinted across open field under intense fire to a shell crater right in front of where the enemy were pushingOur squads MG suppressed the enemy, who were taking cover behind sandbags and small cratersI popped up and started shootingI killed 5 men by myself and pushed the others back, while my teammates prepared for our assault. You know how I said this game made you feel like a small cog?Well that's how it is %99 of the time. But in that %1 percent, you do some amazing thing, like turn back an assault, or charge and breach the line, or mow down the enemy team, and that is what makes this game fun. A balance of teamwork and individual performance affects the outcome of the game, not what loadout you have or the DLC you bought, like many other games. I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a team-based shooter. If you don't like those types of games, just try this one out. You can always refund.

												The game does a fantastic job of portraying the western front of World War 1. The rules after an intial periode of confusion (especially when it comes to unlocking weapons) do a good job of switching the defencive and offensive roles. There are however a few imbalances in terms of uniforms (the french blue and red uniforme for example) and weapons, but these are entirely attributable to the historical accuracy of the game seening as they are an exact copy of the historical versions.

												Verdun is a fun game, however it takes time to learn how to play it well. Verdun is not a brainless shooter like Call of Duty. Now don't take all that "getting your face blown off by some gentlemen with a mustache" to shame, think of it as an inspiration to beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of a kraut with a shovel. This game, in all of its greatness does have its flaws and I'll share with everyone how I fixed a most of them. First off this game is poorly optimized and you will have to make adjustments based on your computer, now this game when I first had it ran between 5-20 FPS on average whether on max. settings or min. settings.My computer runs Windows 10, and I had to disable PreFetch and SuperFetch to make this game and many other games run freaking awesome. I can now play this game on high settings with 55-80 fps on average with AA off. 10/10 would WW1 and optimize settings again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								For hundreds of years, warfare was seen as a right to manhood. A glorious undertaking. Some would even call it "great." As funny as it may sound, the so called Great War would be the very conflict to change our view of, and the history of war, for the rest of time. Sure, some could say that we began to question how glorious war really was with conflicts like the American Civil War, through photographs of the battlefield that made it possible for everyone to see its terror. But it was World War 1, with its global scale and modern technology, that brought the idea of civilized or glorious warfare to a permanent close.   Now, with the release of Verdun, an impressive little game released for harmless recreation, we have another testiment to how horrible the battlefield truly was. While you may have fun charging across No-Man's-Land with your friends, there's no doubt that you will take a look around from time to time, and you can't help but take notice of the blood-soaked fields and mangled corpse-wridden trenches that defined a dark era of our history.   Verdun is a competive team-based game that takes place in the waterlogged trenches of the First World War. The game introduces an interesting squad system that rewards players for working together, improving the gameplay experience and accurately representing the warfare of the time, two effects which give the game tremendous appeal. The game also features engaging and highly-enjoyable gameplay, as players must adapt to the battlefield and the era in order to survive an enemy onslaught, or simply reach the next trench over without joining the ranks of the fallen.    While the game has many attractive features to point out, it's impossible to avoid taking note of the flaws which currently plague an otherwise genius game. Connectivity errors, gameplay glitches, and a few other systematic bugs can greatly damper and even ruin the experience for some players. However, it's also worth mentioning that as an early-beta game, these kinds of things should be EXPECTED to happen, as the development team works to correct key issues and improve the game for everyone.   Overall, I would give the game an 8/10 rating; the best feature of the game being its ability to accurately represent history in a fun and engaging manner, while the worst being the lack of elements that could greatly enhance the game's overall variety and immersion, such as possible units like field medics or engineers. All in all, I would definitely reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys a good multiplayer game, or needs an introduction into the world of pc gaming.    So whether you shout Viva la France or Fur Dass Vaterland, I think it's safe to say that Verdun is a masterful game that anyone can enjoy.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								There aren't a lot of WW1 shooters out there so I was surprised to see this, and even more surprised to see that the servers were fairly well populated. Oh, it's also pretty fun. That being said, its not for everyone, as afterall it is a WW1 shooter. The guns are all single shot rifles or heavy machine guns, and as a result you'll find yourself getting killed pretty often. Its also not the easiest game to get into and does require teamwork inorder to win, one guy with a bolt action rifle isnt going to clear a whole trench by himself. While the game is pretty fun, the battlefield is ruled by snipers which means that you will never see any machine gun nests since they all get sniped out pretty quickly. I think they should add some night levels to make the machine guns more playable and to reduce the amount of snipers, or add rainy levels or something. Overall it's pretty fun, however I think some balancing is needed and sometimes it crashes, although since it's still in beta I'll let that slide. Definitely get this if you're into WW1 history, and even if you're not you might want to consider it.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Great WW1 feel. Large weapon selection. Varied maps for close up trench warfare or battles across no mans land. Specific moments when weapons have advantages such as grenades and flamethrower class in trenches and snipers in long range picking off. Light machine guns are effective in situations too. Rifles are single shot which makes shooting tacticalThe main game mode with most players have games based on attacking an enemy trench line, holding it, and then preparing for the other teams counter attack. Or defending the attack, if you successfully defend then you change to attacking and attack the enemy's foward trench. Battles can go back and forwards, reach stalemates or one team may advance the furthest and win. Its an objective based game, so if you can find people to get on comms with then it can be greatMost guns apart from some pistols are one shot kill, no matter where you hit themRealistic, atmospheric battles with artilery strikes and gas warfareOverall great game if your looking for a tactical shooter with fun/varied weapons, maps and classes. Great battles. This is not like COD, not an arcade run and gun shooterBe warned: you will die a lot when you start out, and still die when you know the game more. This is a realistic game with one shot killing

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												After experiencing Verdun for quite a few months by now, I can see myself fit to write an, at least half-legible, poorly-translated-from-my native-language, review about this fine work of entertainment.Well, this game has offered me something that I have not experienced in quite some years now – heck too many years to be honest; playing a FPS in which I am not bothered by extreme discrepancies between veteran players and fresh recruits; dare I call them like this; and a game that truthly encompasses what a shooter should feel like. There is no pay to win mentality, unlike most triple A shooters. The community is friendly; I haven't met anyone hostile really, well at least not too hostile to be annoying. It’s realistic – yes! ARMA-like realistic – not quite. But truth be said if we were to make a 100% realistic WWI shooter, that would just mean creating a getting-mowed-down-by-machine-guns simulator 2016. It has balance in it, yet the balance is quite subtle. (Don’t get me wrong machine-guns will mow you down, but maybe not as often)For most players that are out there and are tired of all these damn pieces of publicly appealing crap (ahem; COD), Verdun might sound for a good alternative and believe me, it is.Honestly enough I am really glad that I decided to spend 10 Euros on that late May day, deciding to buy this game; it really feels it was worth it.Another strong point to this game is the setting; I mean, to this date, WWI hasn't got its proper fps (yeah, yeah BF1 is coming soon I know; but honestly do you want a somewhat legit representation of The War to End All Wars, or do you want Hollywood-style special effects?). I know that game developers see this historical period as something rather dull; truth is that this war was indeed a meat grinder. And, as the war was, expect to die in this game, and die a lot. Yet despite all this death and misery, you realise the true value of this game and the awesome work the devs have done. I mean they turned one of the saddest and most brutal chapters from the history of mankind into a quite exciting and – well, I say it now - authentic experience.Thus, if you feel it's worth a shot, try this game out; one may be pleasantly surprised by it.19/18 I would go over the top and die... again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												As a person who enjoy realistic tactical shooters like Arma, Insurgency and Squad, Verdun provides realism to the point where the game feels really immersive.Especially how suppressive fire actually suppresses enemies (when bullets flyby near you, your view gets distorted and your aim significantly decreases temporarily) really adds more fun factor to the game.It's also one of the few games which I won't focus on my stats in game but more on achieving objectives. It doesn't matter if someone is playing really bad, nobody will care and continue to focus on their objectives.Also appropriately sized maps don't make you waste so much time getting to the battlefield yet makes flanking possible even with the vast no-man's land to cross.Lastly, you start to notice your teammates more and support them in this game. When I see a squad running towards the enemy trenches, I start to lay down suppressing fire on the enemy so they keep their heads down. Doesn't matter if I hit them, I just fire right over the barracks. If I'm stranded alone in a dug up near the enemy trenches, I'll wait for my squad members to reach me then flank the enemies.Skill matters but a good strategy(or luck) can have a huge impact in the game.Only problems I have with this game are:1. Aiming on some weapons aren't very accurate. I've read some threads on reddit complaining about the same problem.2. In some unbalanced games, enemies were sniping out my team as soon as we respawn.I guess implementing few second invincibility when respawning or finding some new safe respawn zones would fix this problem.3. Some roles are heavily underpowered. Like that one with a mace and three grenades. After you throw those nades, you're basically a human shield?

												110 seconds to live. You will be executed for desertion if you dont return.You are trying to make your way back but people retreating all around are gettting shot in the back. You wait in your pit. You hear those damned frenchies running towards your trench. They are gone. You make a break for THEIR trench. When you get in it you see an enemy sniper and mortor officer. You shoot them. You continue down the trench and kill more. You advance up their right flank. One sees you. After you rush up and bash his face in with your Kar98AZ you continue making your way to your trench. 50 seconds to live. You come up to a large mortor pit with three more in it. Shoot two of them but miss the third. Melee rush. You now have killed 9 people after the retreat whistle sounded. 30 seconds to live. They all know you are there. You see the men in your trench cheering you on, yelling at you to "get back here you stupid private". You look behind you, and see no one. Finally, time to get back to trench. As you rush back to your trench you jump into one of the pits in the front. But as you do so you hear a crack of a sniper rifle...

												100% enjoyable. An FPS unlike most others.  In this day of high tech weapons we fail to to remember the nitty-gritty days of "modern warfare". The Great War was terribly brutal. Millions perished and suffered under this new type of combat. Verdun captures this horror very well. Jump in the Frontlines game mode and witness chaos at it's finest. Just remember to keep your head down and keep pushing forward. All the while keeping away from snipers, machine gunners, grenades, mortar and artillery barrages, airplane scouts, barbwire, and poison gas. If you manage you to make it to the enemy trench unscathed hop in and engage and hold!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have wanted a good World War 1 first person shooter for a long time, and for a long time I heard people say "Oh it would be so boring. You would just charge and get shot down every time."Well now a World War 1 first person shooter is out and just in time for the 100th anniversary. They were partially right. I do charge and get shot down MOST of the time, but just as it says in "All Quiet on the Western Front" the new troops just charge across the open and die. The veterans know how to move along the ground from cover to cover, and getting into the enemy trench and clearing it out with bayonets, knives, clubs, and shovels is so satisfying. Some people say its hard, but if you work with a squad and move as a team its quite easy. The graphics have improved immensely since I first got this game but alas I am currently living over seas for a year and my good gaming computer is back at home so I can't witness this game at full graphics for another 5 or 6 months. The attack and defend with multiple layers of trenches makes for a fun game. You advance. If you are stopped then you fall back and prepare to defend your original trench. If you take their trench then you dig in and prepare to repulse a counter attack. The front is somewhat narrow to give you that World War 1 trench warfare feeling but its not so narrow that its completely impossible to move without dying. Sometimes you can sneak around if the enemy neglects a portion of their line, or you can gas or artillery barrage their lines to force an opening.All in all, if you are looking for a fun, squad based World War 1 first person shooter with a surprising variety of weapons and classes for a war 100 years ago then get this game, and I will see you out in no man's land.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Absolutely love this game.  I have played many FPS games, but this one is definitely unique.  As far as I know this is the only fully fledged WW1 first person shooter.  I have played the WW1 mod for BF1942 which was great, but nothing like this.    Verdun does remind me of Red Orchestra, but I actually enjoy this game more.  I have recently become more interested in everything WWI thanks to a podcast I listen to called Hardcore History by Dan Carlan.  So a couple months back I looked to see if there was a good WWI game that would represent the war well.  This game certainly does.  The trench warfare mode is fantastic and really replicates the fierce battles that those men had to endure.  The mechanics of the game are great.  There is a slight bullet drop, but nothing too noticeable. It is really more realistic than the bullet drop you would experience in Battlefield Bad Company 2.  The maps are fantastic and replicate the uniqueness of the war.  I hope that someday the battles will be increased to 48 or 64 players.  Problem is the server populations are pretty small right now.  Hopefully with the official release of the game more people will play.  This game is pretty difficult.  You will not be able to run and gun like you can in Call of Duty.  If you play Red Orchestra or Battlefield you may be able to not mind the long wait period to respawn.  Successfully capturing a trench will require patience and teamwork.  Gas and artillery strikes will be essential to pull this off in most battles, but this adds to the fun for me.  Highly recommend this game.

"Are we downhearted? No!"Where to start with a game like this? Verdun is the first (to my knowledge) multiplayer FPS set in a realistic First World War setting, which is strangly something no one has attempted before. That being said Verdun offer a completely unique original expierence centered around immersion in a WW1 trench warfare environment. Being a bit of a history junkie myself  I found this game hard to resist and it did not disapoint.GAMEPLAY Verdun's gameplay is based (mainly) around team play, providing you and 3 other players with the ability to form one of the different squad types available to each side respectivly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Ill start by saying this is not COD, so that should be grounds enough to give this a try. PROS:1) realism mechanics: stuck on barbed wire, being gassed, suppresive fire, cardio endurance, must not rush and key jam      while reloading or you will not seat your bolt properly, if you get shot 9/10 times you will die. no sprinting with MGs.2) leadership: in Verdun leadership plays an important role and pushes team play. The NCOs have special abilitys to call in artillery, gas, recon planes and such in order to assist in the battle; making them priceless if used effectively. NCOs can also mark where to focus an attack making it easier to maneuver on the battlefield.3) this game isnt made by your top tier shooter developers so the focus is more about how they care about the game they made and less about how can i nickle and dime my market then move on to the next turd.4) its the only WW1 shooter I know of making it basically an untouched market and I feel anyone would have a hard time making this better overall without more realism mechanics such as first aid application, wounds that bleed out and such.5) the game is very affordable and there are no in game purchases6) THERE IS NO GORE PPPPLEASE ADD GORE or atleast a setting to choose to have it on if you wish.CONS: 1)There arent alot of maps to choose from, although the ones that we do have are not bad (they are providing a free update/expansion with new maps and some other stuff very soon)2) sometimes you will be so sure there is no conceivable way you missed that shot, maybe due to lag but it usualy ends with you being dead and wondering...how?3) no uniform selectable uniform/appearance changes ( you will get new uniforms as your squad progresses but only during that game, once you leave its gone),4) I want to loot corpses for ammo/grenades, and use the enemy firearms if i find one on the battlefield i like better.5) MGs could use some tweaking, they do have limitations but overall i feel they are much too powerful and i dont think you should be able to hip fire a couple of those beasts.thats all i have for now, over all it is a great game for what it is. it can be frustrating but usually its because you are trying to rush ahead like youre playing black ops II. take your time, play the game like a troll trench camper because thats what WWI was. buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												I held my hands over my head as artillery shells exploded around my trench. Dazed, I staggered forward, one goal in mind. "Defend the trench!" my mantra repeated, beating a tattoo into my consciousness. I reached my pillbox. Crouching, I blew my whistle. My men soon came to the pillbox, posting up around me. Shots rang from my gunner as he killed another enemy. "All clear!" I slowly raised myself until I could see out of the makeshift window. I saw movement in some of the underbrush. I called in a mortar shot on that position. Crouching again, I waited, each passing second an eternity. ...........A small hiss rose into earshot. I wondered what it meant as my gunner shouted "Grenade!" The word was not even out of his mouth as a bright flash errupted just outside of the pillbox entrance. I was knocked senseless. Two things crossed my mind as I faded into darkness; my family, and how I would never see them again, and my joy as I heard my mortar shell strike home. The screams of my enemies became a lullaby as I drifted into oblivion.10/10This fps shooter is unlike any I have ever played. Set in WWI era, the bolt action rifle is king. Trenches are your castles, your lives, your tombs. You leave a trench, you die. You stand up, you die. You run zig-zag patterns towards the enemy trench, you die. Somewhere along the way, you start to put everything together. Killing gets easier. You develop a sense of danger, you learn to spot patterns. You discover how close of an ally patience is. Patience leads you to survival, and ultimately, your victory. Pros:-Realistic ballistics-Good balancing-Great bonuses for team playersCons:-No story mode (not complaining about this, just a head's up for players who are looking for some sort of story/campaign.Give it a go. It's definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												A great objective based FPS. If you're obsessed with your KD ratio, it's probably not the game for you,  you'll be screamed at. Focus on the objectives do your job and everything will be fine. When you find a good team to play with, it really shines, each "class" has a unique role that it has to fill otherwise everything becomes way harder for the rest of the squad. WW1 weaponry allows for a different gameplay, compared to all the other machine gun focused modern/WW2 FPS there are.There is a progression system, however it's not central to the game experience, it rewards different play styles and doesn't impose itself on the main game.I'm having a lot of fun, the only downsize is when your team sucks or Yells at each other, but that's something all multiplayer games have in common.

												This game is not like other first person shooters. This is Verdun.I bought this game during the summer sales just because i liked the idea of a WW1 first person shooter, and oh boy have i fallen in love with Verdun. Its all about getting killed during the first couple of hours playing, no matter if you stay in the trenches, crawl through the no-man's-land or attack straight away. These first hours may demotivate new players due to the steep learning curve, but i advise to keep trying and dieing, as the payoff will be great. Everyone should just play this game to experience the horrors of WW1, nothing can describe the feeling of jumping in an enemy trench amidst a gas cloud, sight greatly reduced by your gas mask, and not sure whether you will get stabbed, shot, blown up or if you yourself might stumble upon some unawara Frenchies.Pros:- One shot kills. Don't miss or you're dead.- Graphics- Historical accuracy- Teamplay- Community- New content on regular basis- ...Cons:- Difficulty at start- 16 vs 16 maps, would prefer 32vs32 or 64vs64

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Pretty fun game. It has some cool moments and the maps feel well designed, the flow of the gameplay (attack and counter-attack etc) is good and I like the squad system. Battling through the trenches feels different to most other games (reminds me a bit of Lyes Krovy in Red Orchestra).I have to compare it to Red Orchestra because though they're different periods they're obviously very similar games. So it does feel a bit less polished than RO, the animations aren't as nice, the 'feel' isn't as nice and the ballistics don't feel as good/using weapons doesn't feel as good. The thing I really don't like is how there is no feeling of momentum like in RO, the movement is a bit arcadey because of this; you instantly stop/start moving and when you go prone you have to stop and slowly lower yourself - it just doesn't feel nice compared to RO, where you have momentum and can 'throw' yourself forward when running if you go prone.Honestly I think RO is just better - but that said it is a different game from that and it's worth playing in it's own right, it's also just come out so maybe they'll improve it over time. Probably get it in a sale if you're on the fence, but if RO is your kind of thing then you'll probably like this too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have to say that this is a really good WW1 simulator. You hear the whistle of your NCO, telling you to attack, but deep inside you know that running into No Man's Land will guarantee your quick death. Nonetheless, you go anyways. Even if you crawl, as soon as you pop your head up over that hole, you immediately receive fire. Luckily, they all miss. You reach the enemy trench! Now what? Look, there is your enemy! Quick, shoot him! But the intenseness of the situation makes you miss your shots! You frantically stand up, and charge him with your bayonet. It's your life or his! Even fending off several enemy soldiers, unfortunately your team's attack is repulsed and is driven back. The call to retreat is given.♥♥♥♥♥♥ now youre stuck in the enemy trench!You jump up and attempt to head back to friendly positions. This means that you will have to venture back into the dreaded No Man's Land. Your chances of survival are now at an all time low since your enemy is counterattacking, and is right behind you. And for some odd reason, you survive and jump into your trench, with mortars hitting the ground all around you and gas dropping in poor souls a few yards away. The enemy attack is repulsed, and the time for YOUR counterattack is NOW. This is what makes the game fun and an actual simulator, because WW1 was actually fought like this- a stalemate.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								There aren't a lot of WW1 shooters out there so I was surprised to see this, and even more surprised to see that the servers were fairly well populated. Oh, it's also pretty fun. That being said, its not for everyone, as afterall it is a WW1 shooter. The guns are all single shot rifles or heavy machine guns, and as a result you'll find yourself getting killed pretty often. Its also not the easiest game to get into and does require teamwork inorder to win, one guy with a bolt action rifle isnt going to clear a whole trench by himself. While the game is pretty fun, the battlefield is ruled by snipers which means that you will never see any machine gun nests since they all get sniped out pretty quickly. I think they should add some night levels to make the machine guns more playable and to reduce the amount of snipers, or add rainy levels or something. Overall it's pretty fun, however I think some balancing is needed and sometimes it crashes, although since it's still in beta I'll let that slide. Definitely get this if you're into WW1 history, and even if you're not you might want to consider it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Super fun game. I've been waiting for a long time to play a World War One shooter, probably since Medal of Honor Rising Sun. This game is what I've been waiting for. There's a good squad element, and more strategic than other shooters out there. Verdun is very similar to Red Orchestra 2, with different roles and classes that specialize in certain combat situations. The community is for the most part helpful, there is more material on the way, and overall it is a fun game to play, especially with friends. The game is still in Beta, so not everything is perfect, there are sometimes frame rate drops, glitches(especially with cover system), and hit detection. I think I've only experienced glitches that crashed the game once in the past 70 hours. If you buy this game get used to being shot out of nowhere or shelled inside a trench, there is a bit of a learning curve. Overall it is worth the money. Follow your NCO, keep your head down, and charge for the Kaiser!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								For hundreds of years, warfare was seen as a right to manhood. A glorious undertaking. Some would even call it "great." As funny as it may sound, the so called Great War would be the very conflict to change our view of, and the history of war, for the rest of time. Sure, some could say that we began to question how glorious war really was with conflicts like the American Civil War, through photographs of the battlefield that made it possible for everyone to see its terror. But it was World War 1, with its global scale and modern technology, that brought the idea of civilized or glorious warfare to a permanent close.   Now, with the release of Verdun, an impressive little game released for harmless recreation, we have another testiment to how horrible the battlefield truly was. While you may have fun charging across No-Man's-Land with your friends, there's no doubt that you will take a look around from time to time, and you can't help but take notice of the blood-soaked fields and mangled corpse-wridden trenches that defined a dark era of our history.   Verdun is a competive team-based game that takes place in the waterlogged trenches of the First World War. The game introduces an interesting squad system that rewards players for working together, improving the gameplay experience and accurately representing the warfare of the time, two effects which give the game tremendous appeal. The game also features engaging and highly-enjoyable gameplay, as players must adapt to the battlefield and the era in order to survive an enemy onslaught, or simply reach the next trench over without joining the ranks of the fallen.    While the game has many attractive features to point out, it's impossible to avoid taking note of the flaws which currently plague an otherwise genius game. Connectivity errors, gameplay glitches, and a few other systematic bugs can greatly damper and even ruin the experience for some players. However, it's also worth mentioning that as an early-beta game, these kinds of things should be EXPECTED to happen, as the development team works to correct key issues and improve the game for everyone.   Overall, I would give the game an 8/10 rating; the best feature of the game being its ability to accurately represent history in a fun and engaging manner, while the worst being the lack of elements that could greatly enhance the game's overall variety and immersion, such as possible units like field medics or engineers. All in all, I would definitely reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys a good multiplayer game, or needs an introduction into the world of pc gaming.    So whether you shout Viva la France or Fur Dass Vaterland, I think it's safe to say that Verdun is a masterful game that anyone can enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Great gameplay, great squad mechanics, great atmosphere, this game has it all.The maps are as detailed and as realistic as they can get, I never felt so vulnerable moving around the map in a game before. Getting through no man's land is a matter of luck, you run from cover to cover hoping no one will catch eye on you and be quick to aim and shoot while you're exposed. Trench sweeping is no easier, moving from corner to corner of a trench, hoping to kill the enemy behind it before he catches sight of you. You will die a lot, shot by snipers, crippled by machineguns, maimed by artillery and poisoned by gases. With enough patience and some skill, you can still be able to do the same to the enemy.This game is definitely one of the best multiplayer FPS I've ever played. Props to the dev team for the amount detail, balance, original mechanics and historical accuracy. It could be a bit more polished, but it's already great as it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												This game is an absolute one of a kind gem that you find once in a blue moon on Steam. It's one of those games that is still fun when playing by yourself, but when you have a friend or a group of friends, it really shines. My most memorable experience from this game was when me and my buddy were on attack. We flanked the whole enemy team and got into their trenches. I got hit by artillary which took all my limbs and my head off while my friend ran to seek shelter under ground. All of a sudden my friend says that there is a group of enemies by him, so I tell him to sneak behind some cover and hide until I get there. I immediatly b-lined it towards the trench going through walls of barbed-wire in the No Man's Land dodging bullets and mortars while the rest of my team went through the trenches and distracted the enemy. When I got to the enterance of the underground bunker, I coordinated a surprise attack, and on the count of three my friend and I jumped out and opened fire on five Germans while an epic gunfight took place right above the crumbling bunker we were in. One of the best FPS games out there. 10/10 would open fire again IGN

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Super fun game. I've been waiting for a long time to play a World War One shooter, probably since Medal of Honor Rising Sun. This game is what I've been waiting for. There's a good squad element, and more strategic than other shooters out there. Verdun is very similar to Red Orchestra 2, with different roles and classes that specialize in certain combat situations. The community is for the most part helpful, there is more material on the way, and overall it is a fun game to play, especially with friends. The game is still in Beta, so not everything is perfect, there are sometimes frame rate drops, glitches(especially with cover system), and hit detection. I think I've only experienced glitches that crashed the game once in the past 70 hours. If you buy this game get used to being shot out of nowhere or shelled inside a trench, there is a bit of a learning curve. Overall it is worth the money. Follow your NCO, keep your head down, and charge for the Kaiser!

content:
Posted: March 5
												Verdun - A FPS for people who want a difficult and more realistic shooter.  This is not for people who are looking for another Battlefield/CoD clone. Verdun is a gritty game where most people have bolt action rifles, use iron sights, and have to constantly be on the look out for machine gun fire, gas, and artillery bombardment. The developers made Verdun with realism in mind. You adopt a role within a squad and can choose from one of three layouts for that role. The only cons in this game are a severe lack of kicking abusive players.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I had been shipped off to the Argonne Forest. That fateful day was, oddly quiet, when one day i heard gunshots wizz past my head in the small ditch we passed as a "trench". Oh no! I thought, it's the Germans! I quickly got out of the trench and hid behind a rock. Bullets hit the rock, an inch away from my head. Then we heard our NCO yell: "Germans incoming!" I quickly got back into the trench just as i saw a horde of Germans barreling towards the ditch. One soldier yelled, "MUSTARD GAS!" And the air quickly filled with the green gas as i heard my comrades coughing. I got on my gas mask on, and quickly shot at a German soldier who was infront of me. Suddenly, a bayonet stuck out from infront of me, I realized i had been struck in the back. The bayonet pierced my flesh and it quickly retracted. I got i slight glimpse of my attacker as i was falling, a young man with a gas mask on, a tear trickiling down his eye. Everything went black. Welcome to Verdun.

												Do you like you CoD and your 360 noscoping around? Do you like your killstreaks? Then this isn't the game for you.I adore this game. It is hard and has a steep learning curve. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								After having played 15ish hours of this game, I feel like I can offer my opinion on it and maybe talk about some changes that should be made. First off, Verdun is a unique game in that WW1 is not a widely used setting for an fps. Second, for an early access game it's rather good, although it does have it's issues. One big issue I have is the optimisation, I have a pc that is rather good, and I only get 35~ fps. Another is that I can never get in a lobby that stays full, but I can't really hold that against the developer. Some minor issues that I think could use some work are: with weapons like the Enfield that load using stripper clips, if you've fired five rounds you should just use a stripper clip to load the rifle instead of inserting five individual cartridges. A second issue is the fact that so many classses have pistols, I feel like the game would play better if only the officers, trench raiders, and the machine gunners had sidearms like that. The third and final issue is just with general bugs (scoreboard not scrolling up or down, friends squad system only working when it feels like it, lag, etc..) All in all I think this game is worth the money, and deserves more players than it has playing it. I'll be sure to update this review as time passes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game!  Challenging - You die a lot, but keep on going, wave after wave.  After a while you figure out why you are dieing so often.  Then you see the new recruits, like you were once, doing what you did, and shake your head.  Just like I would imagine being in the trenches.Cooperative gameplay - Each role has a part to play.  Play together with your squad and team for best results.  It is hard to do, but that is the next level I am working on.  When you do, it is even more fun.Realistic - In many ways, such as fatigue, breath holding to steady your shot, bullet drop and aiming in front of a running target, flinching when being shot at, confusion when mortars are falling...  Very exciting.  The developers seem to have realism as a priority, and I am grateful for that.  This is no CoD, that's for sure.Historical settings - Gets me reading about and respecting the soldiers who were there, and what they went through.Nice community of players - I don't know why, but most people who play this game are quite nice and helpful.  Maybe it is the cooperative element, or the historical content.  I don't know, but it is a refreshing community. I hope this doesn't change after release.Fun - This game is fast.  Lots of reaction elements mixed in with thinking about the best move. I can't seem to stop playing...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Verdun is a shining example to other developers, showcasing what a successful 'Early Access' title looks like.Countless numbers of games have entered into 'Early Access,' only to see their developers lose interest once they've already made the bulk of their profits and have no real financial incentive to continue. That is absolutely not the case here--the development team on Verdun clearly has a personal commitment to seeing an online WWI FPS actualized. The most notable part of my experience playing was seeing how often updates and improvements were pushed out, as well as the sheer quality AND quantity; tons of new content, updated textures and animations, improved and balanced gameplay tweaks, performance patches, and even a large overhaul of the game's engine. Not at one single point during the development did it appear as though the developers were living off of their unfinished game, or abusing their fan base's loyalty to work extremely short hours. I'm thrilled to see the official release of this game, as well as it serving as an example of how 'Early Access' was able to positively influence a game throughout development.The game itself is quite fun; the mechanics are fleshed out and very unique. The game modes are nicely objective-oriented without feeling forced or arbitrary. Everything ranging from the game's graphics to its audio feel cohesive, giving an immersive feel of the era. If you've ever wished you could check out a WWI shooter, or simply want to support an indie developer that deserves it, this is your game.Other 'Early Access' developers, TAKE NOTES!

								Solid game,  the only ww1 shooter out there! Developers update with improvements very often. Fun, satisfying, challenging. Good graphics, good sound, gas. Simulates how you would imagine trench warfare battles to play out.So at first i didn't realise you can unlock different classes and weapons by simply clicking the padlock button in the "create squad" menu. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Excellent game! Likes: - Historical weaponry. Lots of single shot weapons, - Constantly getting killed, quick lesson in the necessity to take cover and calculated risks.- The squad based fighting - got to work in teams. Can be an individual but teamwork gives the enemy other people to shoot at! (Murphy's law of war!).- The backwards and forwards of the battle. Sometimes defending, sometimes attacking, but there is always something going on, and you always have to be active!- Having to "go over the top" and the appreciation for fighting your way over no-man's land.- Use of indirect fire support and chemical warfare. GAS GAS GAS! (would be good to have a gas alarm!- Leadership of the NCO is a good feature.Dislikes:- How do you resupply ammo, except for being killed? Why not pick up ammo, or have resupply in the trenches?- Its too clean. Seems all the battles are in summer, in good weather. What about rain, snow, and other adverse conditions?- No mud? The trenches are too tidy. Why not have some flooded?- Why not introduce a medic class? So if a player is wounded, they could be patched up?- There was a learning curve to get to understand some of the games key features. For the first few hours I was just getting killed heaps trying to figure it out. Would be beneficial to make learning the game a bit more intuitive, or to introduce a "training" mission so that newbies can learn the game mechanics prior to battle.- After 17hrs, I've reached game level 7 and I still don't know how to level up and change weapon loadouts... how? Could this be better explained in the game?In summary an innovative and enjoyable game. The attention to history is good. WW1 is an often neglected computer game theme. There's an oversupply of WW2 games, and yet this is the only FPS WW1 game that comes to mind.Overall, excellent game. 8/10.

content:

Early Access Review
								Due to it being an early access game, Verdun is still a bit rough around the edges (mainly with FPS drops on some maps and the animations still need a little bit of work) but I'm still quite impressed at this title. I'm quite pleased how the developers handle WWI with the respect I had hoped. You get a pretty gritty and ugly picture of trench warfare but not to the extent where you can't enjoy the game. The matches are intense as you struggle to defend your position while taking the enemy trenches. Keep in mind, this is not your typical multiplayer shooter such as COD or Battlefield. One shot one kill is standard and you really need to be careful with your positioning on the battlefield.  The community is generally pretty positive and helpful, and the maps are pretty big and nicely laid out. I really hope the developers keep up the great work on this title as with a little more spit and polish, I see great things for this title.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Overall, I'm extremely impressed with this game. The developers really did a good job mixing together interesting historical elements and innovative gameplay features. Unlike CoD-type FPSs where you can get by with spraying and praying with automatic weapons, or you can survive a few body shots, Verdun forces players to rely on their skill to win battles, as most weapons used are bolt-action rifles or pistols that only work up close. On top of that, squad-based strategy is huge in this game as the unique abilities of squad members synergize with each other and prove extremely effective in taking/defending trenches when used correctly. Another impressive feature of the game is the fact that the developers' coherence to historical accuracy actually adds to the quality of gameplay. The countless times you get killed out in no man's land, or blasted away in your trench by unpredictable artillery barrages really gives you an idea of how much of a ♥♥♥♥♥how trench warfare was. This forces players to constantly update their strategies and listen to the commands of their NCO, who generally has his eyes on the whole map. Improvements needed: -Use of "career points" in the Frontlines game mode to upgrade loadouts/abilities in a similar fashion as the Attrition game mode. I'd like the opportunity to diversify my loadout within a squad so I'm not stuck using the same weapon for the duration of my time in a squad. -Decrease the zoom on binoculars, or allow for variable zoom/focus. The only thing binoculars are currently useful for is seeing all the way across the map, which doesn't provide a view of any sort of strategic position. -Add squad member descriptions to the in-game "Squad" tab. If I'm ever in a new or unfamiliar squad, I have to spend 5 minutes accessing the game guide, finding the proper squad in the squad menu, and reading enough of the description to understand what I'm doing. Meanwhile, my team's getting reamed and I'm likely getting kicked for inactivity.-Add a Red Orchestra 2-type tutorial so players don't have to research the game guide to understand how to play the game properly. -Campaign/career mode would be cool if the devs could figure out how to pull it off. Although, in their defense, if it was to be historically accurate, the campaign would consist of your character sitting around in a trench, maybe shooting a few enemies, and then getting blasted by artillery or mowed down in a charge across no man's land, and the character's army would've gotten essentially nowhere by the end of the campaign. An interesting story could probably be told somehow though.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												An excellent game for any fan of "realistic" WW1 Combat. The game functions well,but has some general issues with net coding (e.g. hit registrations) and similar stuff,however,given it's developed by a lesser known studio,it should come to no surprise that such minor things ,that would usually tag a game as unpolished,do occur. The gameplay depitcs WW1 fairy well,with trench warfare and bolt-action rifles being a huge focus. The game is rather slow-paced with matches lasting around 20 minutes.I can recommend this game to any person who is into WW1 and enjoys a realistic take on it in the form of a video game. The game is heavly based around teamwork - there is usually next to no room for solo play,especially when your team is attacking. Besides,rushing an enemy trench with a bunch of people is quite epic to see and most of the time works out well. However,if you are not very fond of dying quite often (especially early on in the game) and like to do things your own way,then you might want to pass on this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												This game offers an experience you just can't find today in games very often. To give you a example of what this game can offer read the following. Me and my friend were moving up with our squad on a night time trench warfare map when I hear the sound of a byplane above. I then see a danger close warning on my screen. Knowing any game, that word usually means bad things are about to happen. My friend, our squad and I proceed to move up with continuous artillery fire raining on our heads. Fighting to get out of harms way we didn't realise we were at the enemy trench already. We are able to kill 1 or 2 soldiers before other people on our team sucessfully breach the right side. We join up with them when out of nowhere a german hostile charges my friend with a bayonet. I quickly line my sights up on the back of the germans head and pull the trigger, thus saving my fellow comrades life. However just because I saved him once doesn't mean he is safe much longer, just after I was able to kill one german, another hostile coming from behind landed a headshot on my friend. In this game I truly feel that even taking out 2 enemies and making way for your team allows a turning point for the rest of the match. At the same time there is never a point where you feel safe. Any skilled player with a rifle or a well placed atillery (also if they are lagging like an elastic band spreading from Japan to the north pole whilst having 300 ping) can lend aid to the enemy. It isn't often you can say that about an online game, let alone one made by 4 developers. This one experience that I have had with the game isn't the only one, it can happen every battle. It is for the above reasons I recommend you purchase this game if you think it is right for you and experience these things for youself.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								for such a small game Verdun has suprisingly become one of my favorite fps games. Now I have only played the game for six ours(at the time of this review being written) but in this short amount of time Verdun keeps on impressing me. Their are two game modes one is free-for-all and the other is front line mode. In front line mode you either start out attacking or defending a trench. Every time your team is successful you get a point and get the opposite oblective of what you just had . As of now there are only four maps but those four maps have been enough for me. The game continues to deliver fun fast paced action every match. One time when defending a trench I found cover and started to shoot french soldiers charging the trench. One by one they continued to fall down until the trench was secured. Another time two of my teamates were pinned down so I went thru the trench we were attacking and when I got to the spot where the enemies were I Just started to line up the shot and took four guys out. The only negatives I could find about this game are that their can be lag there is a limited amount of weapons and their are no unlockable items (so far). Besides that I definitely recomend this game to anyone who likes fps games.
